course_title: Peace and Conflict Amidst Global Disorder

learning_outcomes.description: Understand how changing global order has shaped peace and conflict issues and debates in the contemporary world.
Interpret how contemporary conflicts affect people across cultures and societies.
Critically engage with diverse communities of scholars and practitioners for advancing peace and positive social change.
Explain how ethical theories are justified and inform peace practices and vice versa.

assessments.task_description:
Task description:

This assessment has two parts.

Part 1: Tutorial participation (16 marks)

The first part of this assessment is tutorial participation and is worth 16 marks. In this part, you should participate actively in tutorial discussions.

You will receive 2 marks for participating in each tutorial, in which you are expected to:

  • Read the required reading materials before tutorials and be prepared to engage with discussion questions.
  • Express your own ideas about the content.
  • Show an interest in others’ thoughts and contribute to their development or offer counterarguments.
  • Ask questions for clarification or elaboration.
  • Demonstrate knowledge of the content covered in lectures and tutorials.

If you are unable to attend a tutorial due to extraordinary circumstances, you may have the opportunity to make up the missed mark by submitting a short review of two required readings for that week. You must discuss this with the course coordinator first and then submit the review to your tutor by Friday of the following week. Ongoing work or study commitments are not considered valid reasons.

Part 2: Learning reflection (4 marks)

The second part of this assessment consists of a written learning reflection, due on Friday 24 April (Week 8).

Word length: Maximum 350 words.

In the reflective piece, you should focus on what you learned about the ethical use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in peace and conflict studies. This should be based on readings and tutorial and seminar discussions from Week 7.

Citations and references are not required, but you may include a small number if they help support your reflections. You may write in the first-person language.

The reflections will not be formally assessed, and no feedback will be provided, but they will be checked to ensure you have completed the exercise and are eligible to receive the mark. A very short reflection (for example, less than 100 words) will receive a mark of 0.

This part of the assessment must be submitted via Turnitin. Refer to the Blackboard site for further information.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Task description:

In this assessment, students are required to choose and analyse a conflict case of their choice. The case must fall into one of the following categories:

  • a protracted conflict (drawing on the Week 3 topic), or
  • a conflict driven primarily by economic factors (drawing on the Week 4 topic), or
  • a recently ended conflict (drawing on the Week 5 topic).

Your case analysis must focus primarily on conflict dynamics and processes (avoid elaborate descriptions or extensive historical and economic context), using relevant concepts and theories discussed in the course. It should be clearly structured and organised. You may consider including the following parts in your structure.

Introduction: Briefly introduce your chosen case by identifying the conflict and its context, outlining the key dynamics of the conflict (such as main actors, causes, patterns, or consequences), and clearly stating the focus of your analysis.

Main body: Apply one key theory or a set of closely related theoretical concepts (selected from the unit readings and lectures) relevant to your case. This part should include your main case analysis, applying a concept or theory to illustrate the nature and dynamics of the conflict.

Conclusion: Reflect briefly on your use of theory by explaining how the selected theory or concepts helped you understand the case, and discuss the extent to which the theory was useful or limited in analysing the conflict.

The total word length is 1500 words, excluding references (a 10% leeway is accepted).

Refer to the Blackboard site for marking criteria and the Turnitin submission link.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
In no more than 1500 words, write a policy briefing paper that responds to the following question:

Why does Australia need a clear conflict prevention strategy, and what approaches should such a strategy include to help prevent conflicts in the Asia–Pacific region?

This assessment requires you to apply theories and concepts from the course to a real-world policy challenge. Your task is to analyse Australia’s current approach to conflict prevention and make a case for Australia’s conflict prevention strategy.

You should imagine that you are writing this piece for a non-academic audience, specifically, the community of policymakers in Australia. This means your writing should be clear, concise, and accessible.

In your briefing paper, consider including the following:

  • Explain why a conflict prevention strategy matters for Australia in today’s regional and global context.
  • Examine Australia’s current approaches and strategies for conflict prevention, identifying strengths and gaps.
  • Draw lessons from other countries’ strategies (e.g., the UK, Sweden, Norway) and consider whether Australia could learn from these approaches.
  • Propose key approaches or elements that a stronger conflict prevention strategy should include for Australia in the Asia–Pacific region.
  • Conclude with a small number of practical policy recommendations.

Your proposed approach does not need to be detailed or comprehensive; instead, outline principles, priorities, and possible areas for action. Support your analysis with relevant concepts and debates from the course.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
The end of semester exam is worth 30 % of the total mark.

Timing: Examination period (6-20 June)

The exam will take place in person and on campus during the exam period. UQ will schedule the date and time of the written exam during the examination period (6-20 June).

You will be required to write three short answers (350 - 400 words maximum) from a choice of seven questions (each answer is worth 10 marks, i.e. 30 marks in total).

The exam questions will be based on topics covered in the course. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
